description.narrative: The Transfer Project is a multi-country research and learning initiative that is intended to further our knowledge about the impacts of social cash transfers in Africa. The project aims to generate evidence-based knowledge to inform design of policies and programs for social cash transfers in Africa. Through an additional contribution of 500 000 SEK an additional activity can be undertaken that was not previously included in the plan and which will increase knowledge about social cash transfers in fragile contexts.

Transferprojektet är ett forsknings och utvärderingsinitiativ som syftar till att stärka kunskap om effekterna av sociala trygghetssystem med kontantstöd i Afrika. Projektet syftar till att ta fram evidensbaserad kunskap för att informera utforming av policyer och program för att genomföra sociala kontantstöd i Afrika. Genom ett tillskott om 500 000 SEK kan ytterligare en aktivitet genomföras som inte tidigare var förutsedd och som kommer att bidra till ökad kunskap om sociala kontantstöd i fragila kontexter.

sector.narrative: Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: This intervention is linked to the intervention 51000177 and is part of the overall results achievement of this project. Results have been achieved in all results areas, with some of the key achievements highlighted below. Several peer-reviwed articles and working papers have been published, and one major achievement is a culminating study that debunks myths around transfer which was finalised in 2017. Using data from eight Transfer Project impact evaluations in seven countries (Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe), the study combats perceptions about unconditional cash transfers as poverty reducation strategies in Africa, such as "cash transfers are wasted on alcohol and tobacco", "cash transfer to households young children will increase fertility" etc. Another key milestone includes the publication of the book compendium titled "From Evidence to Action: The Story of Cash Transfers and Impact Evaluation in Sub-Saharan Africa". With Sida funding, the Transfer Project has also provided support to six early career, African research fellows at Innocenti. In 2016, a research partnership agreement with African Economic Research Consortium (AERC) was finalised, and Innocenti-researchers led an impact evaluation workshop for 20 PhD students at AERC's bi-annual conference in Dakar using Transfer Project data. Another result to be highlighted is the Transfer Project bi-annual regional research workshop in 2017, held in Dakar, Senegel. The workshop gathered 120 participants, the majority representing African governments or implementing agencies from 24 different African countries and provided sharing of latest research and exchange of experience between policy makers and researchers in Africa. The Transfer project has continously provided technical assistance and oversight over impact evaluations, and in total 14 rounds of data collection were conducted in Ghana, Tanzania, Zambia, Malawi and Zimbabwe during the project period, exceeding the number of planned rounds initially proposed (3).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
